title.narrative: Research on Youth issues in Pakistan

description.narrative: The present study aims to explore the lives of Transgender (TG) and HIV patients and their families and service/care providers in Rawalpindi, Multan, Abbotabad, Umerkot and Mardan. The first part will be quantitative in nature aiming at collecting the profiles ofTG in mentioned districts. This study will look into different issues in the life of TG e.g. health aspect including emotional and physical wellbeing, political participation and awareness, dynamics of religious practices, social roles and intracommunity dynamics. Second part of the project will be focusing on Acquired immune efficiency syndrome and will be focusing on assessing the socio-economic and psychological implications of HIV/AIDS on the patients, their families and overall community. This will look into knowledge, beliefs, myths and misconceptions regarding the cause, transmission and prevention of HIV/AIDS. The project will study the role of family as an institution in the prevalence of HIV/AIDS and to find out religious, social, economic and cultural barriers involved in the treatment of HIV/AIDS. To investigate the discrimination and stigmatization experienced by HIV infected patients? Data will be collected through mix method approach i.e. qualitative and quantitative. Survey research will used to document the profiles of TG.Whereas researchers will be using pure anthropological methods like participant observation, focus group discussions, in-depth interviews and life histories to explore their respective variables. The holistic approach of anthropological inquiry will make this study unique. This will give a quite comprehensive contextual understanding of the phenomenon understudy. This project will also build the capacity of the department of anthropology in terms of computers for research, audio visual editing equipment for visual anthropology laboratory, seed money for establishing ethnology museum, equipment for class rooms. The department of Anthropology hosts students from all across Pakistan, especially rural areas. The department#s infrastructure needs revamping and this capacity buildingdrive of Oxfam will help to educate students for decades.

participating-org.narrative: Department of Anthropology Quaid-i-Azam University Islamabad

Department of Anthropology aims at developing students to understand themselves as embedded within and products of social and cultural contexts. Our students are trained to have the relational and analytic tools to operate effectively within the social complexityof our dynamic world and engage people cross-culturally, both in Pakistan and abroad. Students will become critical thinkers, addressing social problems and positively engaging in cultural analysis through theory, data, and practical solutions. The Department of Anthropology at Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad has the distinction of being the first and, as of now, the only and full fledge department in the country. It was established in 1974 under a program of collaboration with the Universities of Pennsylvania (USA) and Heidelberg (Germany). The Department was established with the efforts of Prof. Dr. Ahmad Hassan Dani (Late). In August 1976 Prof. Dr. Muhammad MA Rauf was appointed as the first Chairman of the Department. Presently, Prof. Dr. Hafeez ur Rehman Chaudhary is the chairman of the department.
The general goal of the department is to develop an analytical foundation for understanding social interaction both within Pakistani society and across cultures. The faculty duly communicates the gospel of its subject matter at several levels of social interaction. The micro level involves face-to-face communication, for example, in marriage or the family; the middle-range level reflects activities in organizations or social movements; and the macro level presents issues of culture and societal structures. At each level, social processes such as socialization, stratification, urbanization, and social disorganization are examined. The anthropology faculty emphasizes both the particularities of varying cultural systems, as well as the universal characteristics of humans made in the image of mankind. Recognizing culture as a set of only partial solutions to human problems, Anthropology faculty also examine the ways in which the gospel and culture can operate jointly to explain human adaptations in different societies.
